Mecanismos de Rango de Negociación: Explorando los Límites de los Mercados Eficientes y Veraces. Yair Bartal ∗ Escuela de Ciencias de la Computación e Ingeniería Universidad Hebrea de Jerusalén, Israel yair@cs.huji.ac.il Rica Gonen Escuela de Ciencias de la Computación e Ingeniería Universidad Hebrea de Jerusalén, Israel rgonen@cs.huji.ac.il Pierfrancesco La Mura Escuela de Posgrado de Administración de Leipzig, Leipzig, Alemania plamura@hhl.de RESUMEN Este artículo introduce una nueva clase de mecanismos basados en la negociación entre participantes del mercado. Este modelo nos permite sortear el resultado de imposibilidad de Myerson y Satterthwaite y presentar un mecanismo de mercado bilateral que es eficiente, racional individualmente, compatible con incentivos y equilibrado presupuestariamente en el entorno de unidades individuales heterogéneas. El esquema subyacente hace posible esta combinación de cualidades deseables al informar un rango de precios para cada par de comprador-vendedor que define una zona de posibles acuerdos, mientras que el precio final queda abierto para negociación. Categorías y Descriptores de Asignaturas J.4 [Ciencias Sociales y del Comportamiento]: Economía; K.4.4 [Computadoras y Sociedad]: Comercio Electrónico-esquemas de pago Términos Generales Algoritmos, Economía, Teoría 1. En este artículo introducimos el concepto de mecanismos de negociación en el contexto de la teoría de mercados eficientes y veraces. Un mercado está compuesto por múltiples compradores y vendedores que desean intercambiar bienes. El objetivo principal del mercado es producir una asignación de bienes de vendedores a compradores de manera que se maximice la ganancia total del intercambio. Un modelo comúnmente estudiado de comportamiento de participantes se toma del campo del diseño de mecanismos económicos [3, 4, 11]. En este modelo, cada jugador tiene una función de valoración privada que asigna valores reales a cada asignación posible. El algoritmo motiva a los jugadores a participar honestamente entregándoles pagos. El mecanismo en un intercambio recopila las ofertas de compra y venta de los compradores y vendedores y liquida el intercambio calculando: (i) un conjunto de transacciones, y (ii) los pagos realizados y recibidos por los participantes. Al diseñar un mecanismo para calcular intercambios y pagos, debemos considerar las estrategias de oferta de los jugadores interesados, es decir, jugadores racionales que siguen estrategias de maximización de utilidad esperada. Establecimos la eficiencia allocativa como nuestro objetivo principal. Ese es el mecanismo que debe calcular un conjunto de operaciones que maximice la ganancia del comercio. Además, requerimos racionalidad individual (RI) para que todos los jugadores tengan una utilidad esperada positiva al participar, equilibrio presupuestario (EP) para que el intercambio no genere pérdidas, e incentivos compatibles (IC) para que reportar la verdad sea una estrategia dominante para cada jugador. Desafortunadamente, el resultado bien conocido de Myerson y Satterthwaite (1983) demuestra que en el comercio bilateral es imposible lograr simultáneamente una eficiencia perfecta, BB e IR utilizando un mecanismo de CI [10]. Un enfoque único para superar el resultado de imposibilidad de Myerson y Satterthwaite fue intentado por Parkes, Kalagnanam y Eso [12]. Este resultado diseña tanto un mecanismo de comercio bilateral regular como combinatorio (que impone BB e IR) que aproxima la revelación de la verdad y la eficiencia de asignación. En este documento evitamos el resultado imposible de Myerson y Satterthwaite al introducir un nuevo modelo de mercados de negociación de rango. Un mecanismo de rango de negociación no produce precios de pago para los participantes del mercado. Más bien, asigna a cada par comprador-vendedor un rango de precios, llamado Zona de Posibles Acuerdos (ZOPA). Al comprador se le proporciona el extremo superior del rango y al vendedor el extremo inferior del rango. Esto permite a las partes comerciantes participar en negociaciones sobre el precio final con la garantía de que el acuerdo sea beneficioso para ambos. El proceso de negociación no se considera parte del mecanismo, sino que queda a cargo de las partes interesadas o de algún mecanismo externo para llevarlo a cabo. De hecho, un mecanismo de rango de negociación actúa como mediador entre los participantes del mercado, ofreciéndoles las bases para poder finalizar los términos del intercambio por sí mismos. Este concepto es natural en muchos entornos de mercado del mundo real, como el mercado inmobiliario. Nos enfocamos en el entorno heterogéneo de unidades individuales: n vendedores ofrecen un bien único cada uno mediante la presentación de ofertas selladas que especifican su disposición a vender, y m compradores, interesados en comprar un bien único cada uno, presentan ofertas selladas que especifican su disposición a pagar por cada bien en el que puedan estar interesados. Nuestro resultado principal es un mecanismo de negociación de comercio bilateral heterogéneo de unidad única (ZOPAS) que es eficiente, individualmente racional, compatible con incentivos y equilibrado presupuestariamente. Nuestro resultado no contradice el importante teorema de Myerson y Satterthwaite. La demostración de Myerson-Satterthwaite se basa en un teorema que asegura que en dos mercados IC eficientes diferentes; si los vendedores tienen la misma utilidad máxima límite, entonces recibirán los mismos precios en cada mercado y si los compradores tienen la misma utilidad mínima límite, entonces recibirán los mismos precios en cada mercado. Nuestro mecanismo heterogéneo de unidad única evita el teorema de Myerson y Satterthwaite al producir un rango de precios, definido por un límite del vendedor y un techo del comprador, para cada par de jugadores emparejados. En nuestro mecanismo de mercado, la utilidad máxima del vendedor puede ser la misma, mientras que el límite inferior del vendedor es diferente y la utilidad mínima del comprador puede ser la misma, mientras que el techo del comprador es diferente. Además, el precio final no está fijado en absoluto por el mecanismo. En cambio, se determina mediante una negociación independiente entre el
comprador y el vendedor
. Más específicamente, en un mecanismo de rango de negociación, el rango de precios de cada par emparejado se resuelve mediante una etapa de negociación donde se determina un precio final. Esta etapa de negociación es crucial para que nuestro mecanismo sea IC. De manera intuitiva, un mecanismo de rango de negociación es compatible con incentivos si decir la verdad promete la mejor ZOPA desde el punto de vista del jugador en cuestión. Es decir, él diría la verdad si esta estrategia maximiza los límites superiores e inferiores de su utilidad expresados por los límites de la ZOPA. Sin embargo, cuando se examina detenidamente, resulta que es imposible (por [10]) que este objetivo se cumpla siempre. Esto se debe simplemente a que dicho mecanismo podría ser fácilmente modificado para determinar los precios finales de los jugadores (por ejemplo, tomando el promedio de los límites de los rangos). Aquí es donde entra en juego la etapa de negociación. Mostramos que si la condición de maximización de utilidad anterior no se cumple, entonces el jugador no puede influir en el límite de negociación asignado a su compañero de negociación, sin importar el valor que declare. Esto significa que lo único que podría lograr al informar una valoración falsa es modificar su propio límite de negociación, algo que podría lograr alternativamente al informar su verdadera valoración e incorporar el efecto del límite de negociación modificado en su estrategia de negociación. Esto elimina el beneficio de reportar valoraciones falsas y permite que nuestro mecanismo calcule la ganancia óptima del intercambio según los valores reales de los jugadores. El problema de calcular la asignación óptima que maximiza la ganancia del comercio se puede conceptualizar como el problema de encontrar el emparejamiento ponderado máximo en un grafo bipartito ponderado que conecta compradores y vendedores, donde cada arista en el grafo se le asigna un peso igual a la diferencia entre la oferta del comprador respectivo y la oferta del vendedor. Es bien sabido que este problema puede resolverse eficientemente en tiempo polinómico. Los esquemas de pago VCG IC [2, 7, 13] apoyan el comercio bilateral eficiente y IR, pero no simultáneamente BB. Nuestro enfoque particular adapta el esquema de pago VCG para lograr un equilibrio presupuestario. La filosofía de los esquemas de pago VCG en el comercio bilateral es que el comprador paga el costo de oportunidad del vendedor por no vender el bien a otro comprador y por no quedarse con el bien para sí mismo. El vendedor recibe, además del precio del comprador, una compensación por el daño que el mecanismo le causó al vendedor al no extraer la oferta completa del comprador. Nuestra filosofía es un poco diferente: El vendedor recibe al menos su costo de oportunidad por no vender el bien a otro comprador y por no quedarse con el bien para sí mismo. El comprador paga como máximo el costo de oportunidad de sus vendedores alternativos por no vender el bien a otro comprador y por no quedarse con el bien alternativo para sí mismo. El resto de este documento está organizado de la siguiente manera. En la Sección 2 describimos nuestro modelo y definiciones. En la sección 3 presentamos el mecanismo de negociación de rango heterogéneo de unidad única y demostramos que es eficiente, IR, IC y BB. Finalmente, concluimos con una discusión en la Sección 4.2. MERCADOS DE NEGOCIACIÓN PRELIMINARES Sea Π el conjunto de jugadores, N el conjunto de n jugadores vendedores y M el conjunto de m jugadores compradores, donde Π = N ∪ M. Sea Ψ = {1, ..., t} el conjunto de bienes. Que Ti ∈ {−1, 0, 1}t denote un vector de intercambio para un comercio, de modo que el jugador i compra bienes {A ∈ Ψ|Ti (A) = 1} y vende bienes {A ∈ Ψ|Ti (A) = −1}. Sea T = (T1, ..., T|Π|) el comercio completo entre todos los jugadores. Vemos a T como la descripción de la asignación de bienes por el mecanismo a los compradores y vendedores. En el entorno heterogéneo de unidad única, cada bien pertenece a un vendedor específico y cada comprador está interesado en comprar un bien. El comprador puede hacer una oferta por varios o todos los bienes. Al final de la subasta, cada bien es asignado a uno de los compradores que pujaron por él o se mantiene sin vender por el vendedor. Es conveniente asumir que los conjuntos de compradores y vendedores son disjuntos (aunque no es necesario), es decir, N ∩ M = ∅. Cada vendedor i está asociado exactamente con un bien Ai, para el cual tiene una valuación ci verdadera que expresa el precio al cual le resulta beneficioso vender el bien. Si el vendedor informa una valuación falsa en un intento de mejorar los resultados de la subasta para él, esta valuación se denota ˆci. Un comprador tiene un vector de valoración que describe su valoración por cada uno de los bienes según su propietario. Específicamente, vj(k) denota la valoración del comprador j para el bien Ak. De manera similar, si informa una valuación falsa se denota ˆvj(k). Si el comprador j es emparejado por el mecanismo con el vendedor i, entonces Ti(Ai) = −1 y Tj(Ai) = 1. Observa que en nuestro entorno, para cada k = i, Ti(Ak) = 0 y Tj(Ai) = 0 y también para cada z = j, Tz(Ai) = 0. Para un par de comprador j - vendedor i emparejado, la ganancia del intercambio en el acuerdo se define como vj(i) − ci. Dada una asignación T, la ganancia del comercio asociada con T es V = j∈M,i∈N (vj(i) − ci) · Tj(Ai). Que T∗ denote la asignación óptima que maximiza la ganancia del intercambio, calculada de acuerdo a las valoraciones reales de los jugadores. Que V ∗ denote la ganancia óptima del intercambio asociada con esta asignación. Cuando los jugadores informan valoraciones falsas, usamos ˆT∗ y ˆV ∗ para denotar la asignación óptima y la ganancia del intercambio, respectivamente, cuando se calculan según las valoraciones informadas. Estamos interesados en el diseño de mecanismos de rango de negociación. A diferencia de un mecanismo de subasta estándar donde al
comprador y al vendedor
se les proporcionan los precios que deben pagar, el objetivo de un mecanismo de rango de negociación es proporcionar a los jugadores un rango de precios dentro del cual puedan negociar los términos finales del acuerdo por sí mismos. El mecanismo proporcionaría al comprador el límite superior del rango y al vendedor el límite inferior del rango. Esto les da a cada uno de ellos la promesa de que les será beneficioso cerrar el trato, pero no proporciona información sobre los términos de negociación de los otros jugadores. Definición 1. Rango de negociación: Zona de Posibles Acuerdos, ZOPA, entre un comprador y un vendedor emparejados. El ZOPA es un rango, (L, H), 0 ≤ L ≤ H, donde H es un precio límite superior para el comprador y L es un precio límite inferior para el vendedor. Definición 2. Mecanismo de Rango de Negociación: Un mecanismo que calcula una ZOPA, (L, H), para cada
comprador y vendedor
emparejados en T∗, y proporciona al comprador el límite superior H y al vendedor el límite inferior L. La suposición básica es que los participantes en la subasta son jugadores interesados en sí mismos. Su principal objetivo es maximizar su utilidad esperada. La utilidad para un comprador que no participa en el intercambio es 0. Si gana algo bueno, su utilidad es el excedente entre su valoración por ese bien y el precio que paga. Para un vendedor, si mantiene el bien sin vender, su utilidad es simplemente su valoración del bien, y el excedente es 0. Si logra venderlo, su utilidad es el precio que se le paga por él, y el excedente es la diferencia entre este precio y su valoración. Dado que los mecanismos de negociación de rango asignan límites en el rango de precios en lugar del precio final, es útil definir los límites superiores e inferiores en las utilidades de los jugadores definidos por los límites de los rangos. Definición 3. Considera un par comprador j - vendedor i emparejado por un mecanismo de rango de negociación y deja que (L, H) sea su rango de negociación asociado. • La utilidad máxima del comprador es: vj(i) − L, y la utilidad mínima del comprador es vj(i) − H. • La utilidad máxima del vendedor es H, con un excedente H − ci, y la utilidad mínima del vendedor es L, con un excedente L − ci. 3. El Mecanismo Heterogéneo de Unidad Única (ZOPAS) 3.1 Descripción del Mecanismo ZOPAS es un mecanismo de rango de negociación, encuentra la asignación óptima T∗ y la utiliza para definir una ZOPA para cada par de comprador-vendedor. La primera etapa en aplicar el mecanismo es que los compradores y vendedores presenten sus ofertas selladas. El mecanismo luego asigna compradores a vendedores calculando la asignación T ∗, que resulta en la ganancia óptima del intercambio V ∗, y define una ZOPA para cada par comprador-vendedor. Finalmente, los compradores y vendedores utilizan la ZOPA para negociar un precio final. Calcular T∗ implica resolver el problema de emparejamiento bipartito ponderado máximo para el grafo bipartito completo Kn,m construido colocando a los compradores en un lado del grafo. Encuentre la asignación óptima T∗. Calcule el emparejamiento bipartito ponderado máximo para el grafo bipartito de compradores y vendedores, con pesos en las aristas iguales a la ganancia del intercambio. Calcular los pisos de los vendedores Para cada comprador j, asignar el bien Ai Encuentre la asignación óptima (T−j)∗ Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ Calcular los techos de los compradores Para cada comprador j, asignar el bien Ai Encuentre la asignación óptima (T −i )∗ Encuentre la asignación óptima (T −i −j )∗ Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗ Fase de negociación Para cada comprador j y cada vendedor i del bien Ai Informar al vendedor i su piso Li e identificar a su comprador j emparejado Informar al comprador j su techo Hj e identificar a su vendedor i emparejado i, j negocian el precio final de los bienes Figura 1: El gráfico del mecanismo ZOPAS, el vendedor en otro y dando al borde entre el comprador j y el vendedor i un peso igual a vj(i) − ci. El problema de emparejamiento ponderado máximo es soluble en tiempo polinómico (por ejemplo, utilizando el Método Húngaro). Esto resulta en una coincidencia entre compradores y vendedores que maximiza la ganancia del intercambio. El siguiente paso es calcular para cada par comprador-vendedor un límite inferior del vendedor, que proporciona el límite inferior de la ZOPA para este par, y asignarlo al vendedor. El excedente del vendedor se calcula mediante la diferencia entre la ganancia total del intercambio cuando se excluye al comprador y la ganancia total del intercambio de los demás participantes cuando se incluye al comprador (principio de VCG). Que (T−j)∗ denote la ganancia del comercio de la asignación óptima cuando se descartan las ofertas del comprador j. Denote por (V−j)∗ la ganancia total del comercio en la asignación (T−j)∗. Definición 4. Precio de Venta Mínimo: El precio más bajo que el vendedor debería esperar recibir, comunicado al vendedor por el mecanismo. El piso de venta para el jugador i que fue emparejado con el comprador j en el bien Ai, es decir, Tj(Ai) = 1, se calcula como: Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ . Se instruye al vendedor a no aceptar menos de este precio de su comprador emparejado. A continuación, el mecanismo calcula para cada par comprador-vendedor un techo para el comprador, que proporciona el límite superior de la ZOPA para este par, y lo asigna al comprador. El techo de cada comprador se calcula eliminando al vendedor emparejado con el comprador y calculando la diferencia entre la ganancia total del intercambio cuando el comprador es excluido y la ganancia total del intercambio de los otros participantes cuando se incluye al tercer comprador. Que (T−i )∗ denote la ganancia del intercambio de la asignación óptima cuando se elimina al vendedor i del comercio. Denote por (V −i )∗ la ganancia total del comercio en la asignación (T−i )∗. Que (T−i −j )∗ denote la ganancia del comercio de la asignación óptima cuando se elimina al vendedor i del comercio y se descartan las ofertas de los compradores js. Denote por (V −i −j )∗ la ganancia total del comercio en la asignación (T −i −j )∗. Definición 5. Techo del comprador: El precio más alto que el vendedor debería esperar pagar, comunicado al comprador por el mecanismo. El límite de compra para el jugador j que fue emparejado con el vendedor i en el bien Ai, es decir, Tj(Ai) = 1, se calcula como: Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗. Se instruye al comprador a no pagar más de este precio a su vendedor correspondiente. Una vez que se calculan los límites inferior y superior del rango de negociación para cada par coincidente, el mecanismo informa el precio límite inferior al vendedor y el precio límite superior al comprador. En este punto, cada par comprador-vendedor negocia el precio final y concluye el acuerdo. El mecanismo de negociación de rango de mercado ZOPAS es un mecanismo de comercio bilateral compatible con incentivos que es eficiente, racional individualmente y equilibrado presupuestariamente. Claramente ZOPAS es un mecanismo eficiente de tiempo polinómico. Mostremos que cumple con el resto de las propiedades en el teorema. Reclamo 1. ZOPAS es racional individualmente, es decir, el mecanismo mantiene un excedente de utilidad no negativo para todos los participantes. Prueba. Si un participante no intercambia en la asignación óptima, entonces su excedente de utilidad es cero por definición. Considera un par de comprador j y vendedor i que están emparejados en la asignación óptima T ∗. Entonces, la utilidad de los compradores es al menos vj(i) − Hj. Recuerde que Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗ , de modo que vj(i) − Hj = (V −i )∗ − (V −i −j )∗ . Dado que la ganancia óptima del intercambio que incluye a j es mayor que la que no lo incluye, tenemos que la utilidad es no negativa: vj(i) − Hj ≥ 0. Ahora, considera al vendedor i. Su excedente de utilidad es al menos Li − ci. Recuerde que Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ . Si eliminamos de la asignación óptima T ∗ la contribución del par comprador j - vendedor i, nos queda una asignación que excluye a j, y tiene un valor V ∗ − (vj(i) − ci). Esto implica que (V−j)∗ ≥ V ∗ − vj(i) + ci, lo cual implica que Li − ci ≥ 0. El hecho de que ZOPAS sea un mecanismo equilibrado en presupuesto se deriva del siguiente lema que garantiza la validez del rango de negociación, es decir, que el precio mínimo de cada vendedor esté por debajo del precio máximo de sus compradores emparejados. Esto asegura que puedan cerrar el trato a un precio final que se encuentre en este rango. Lema 1. Para cada par de comprador j y vendedor i emparejado por el mecanismo: Li ≤ Hj. Prueba. Recuerde que Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ y Hj = vj(i)+(V −i −j )∗ −(V −i )∗. Para demostrar que Li ≤ Hj, basta con mostrar que (V −i )∗ + (V−j)∗ ≤ V ∗ + (V −i −j )∗. La prueba de (1) se basa en un método que aplicamos varias veces en nuestro análisis. Empezamos con las asignaciones (T−i)∗ y (T−j)∗ que juntas tienen un valor igual a (V−i)∗ + (V−j)∗. Ahora los usamos para crear un par de nuevas asignaciones válidas, utilizando los mismos pares que fueron emparejados en las asignaciones originales. Esto significa que la suma de los valores de las nuevas asignaciones es la misma que la del par original de asignaciones. También requerimos que una de las nuevas asignaciones no incluya al comprador j o al vendedor i. Esto significa que la suma de los valores de estas nuevas asignaciones es a lo sumo V ∗ + (V −i −j )∗, lo cual demuestra (1). Sea G el grafo bipartito donde los nodos de un lado de G representan a los compradores y los nodos del otro lado representan a los vendedores, y los pesos de las aristas representan la ganancia del intercambio para el par particular. El excedente de utilidad se define como la diferencia absoluta entre la oferta del jugador y su precio. Los mecanismos de rango de negociación asignan límites en el rango de precios en lugar del precio final y, por lo tanto, la valoración de los jugadores solo influye en los límites mínimo y máximo de su utilidad. Para un comprador, la utilidad mínima estaría basada en la parte superior del rango de negociación (techo), y la utilidad máxima estaría basada en la parte inferior del rango de negociación (suelo). Para un vendedor es al revés. Por lo tanto, el requisito natural básico de los mecanismos de negociación sería que al declarar la verdadera valoración de los jugadores se obtengan tanto una utilidad mínima más alta como una utilidad máxima más alta para el jugador, en comparación con otras estrategias. Desafortunadamente, este requisito sigue siendo demasiado estricto y es imposible (por [10]) que esto se cumpla siempre. Por lo tanto, lo relajamos ligeramente de la siguiente manera: requerimos que esto se cumpla cuando la estrategia basada en la valoración falsa cambia la asignación de los jugadores. Cuando la asignación permanece sin cambios, requerimos en su lugar que el jugador no pueda cambiar el límite de los jugadores emparejados (por ejemplo, un comprador no puede cambiar el precio mínimo del vendedor). Esto significa que lo único que puede influir es su propio límite, algo que puede lograr alternativamente a través de medios de negociación. Lo siguiente resume formalmente nuestros requisitos de compatibilidad de incentivos del mecanismo de rango de negociación. En particular, no es posible para el vendedor i que está emparejado en T ∗ cambiar a su comprador reportando una valuación falsa. Este hecho simplemente se deriva de la observación de que reducir la valoración de los vendedores aumenta la ganancia del intercambio para la asignación actual al menos tanto como cualquier otra asignación, mientras que aumentar la valoración de los vendedores disminuye la ganancia del intercambio para la asignación actual exactamente en la misma cantidad que cualquier otra asignación en la que se empareje. original_annotated_sentences: Negotiation-Range Mechanisms: Exploring the Limits of Truthful Efficient Markets Yair Bartal ∗ School of Computer Science and Engineering The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel yair@cs.huji.ac.il Rica Gonen School of Computer Science and Engineering The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel rgonen@cs.huji.ac.il Pierfrancesco La Mura Leipzig Graduate School of Management Leipzig, Germany plamura@hhl.de ABSTRACT This paper introduces a new class of mechanisms based on negotiation between market participants.

This model allows us to circumvent Myerson and Satterthwaites impossibility result and present a bilateral market mechanism that is efficient, individually rational, incentive compatible and budget balanced in the single-unit heterogeneous setting.

The underlying scheme makes this combination of desirable qualities possible by reporting a price range for each buyer-seller pair that defines a zone of possible agreements, while the final price is left open for negotiation.
Categories and Subject Descriptors J.4 [Social and Behavioral Sciences]: Economics; K.4.4 [Computers and Society]: Electronic Commerce-payment schemes General Terms Algorithms, Economics, Theory 1.
INTRODUCTION In this paper we introduce the concept of negotiation based mechanisms in the context of the theory of efficient truthful markets.
A market consists of multiple buyers and sellers who wish to exchange goods.
The markets main objective is to produce an allocation of sellers goods to buyers as to maximize the total gain from trade.
A commonly studied model of participant behavior is taken from the field of economic mechanism design [3, 4, 11].
In this model each player has a private valuation function that assigns real values to each possible allocation.
The algorithm motivates players to participate truthfully by handing payments to them.
The mechanism in an exchange collects buyer bids and seller bids and clears the exchange by computing:(i) a set of trades, and (ii) the payments made and received by players.
In designing a mechanism to compute trades and payments we must consider the bidding strategies of self-interested players, i.e. rational players that follow expected-utility maximizing strategies.
We set allocative efficiency as our primary goal.
That is the mechanism must compute a set of trades that maximizes gain from trade.

In addition we require individual rationality (IR) so that all players have positive expected utility to participate, budget balance (BB) so that the exchange does not run at a loss, and incentive compatibility (IC) so that reporting the truth is a dominant strategy for each player.

Unfortunately, Myerson and Satterthwaites (1983) well known result demonstrates that in bilateral trade it is impossible to simultaneously achieve perfect efficiency, BB, and IR using an IC mechanism [10].
A unique approach to overcome Myerson and Satterthwaites impossibility result was attempted by Parkes, Kalagnanam and Eso [12].
This result designs both a regular and a combinatorial bilateral trade mechanism (which imposes BB and IR) that approximates truth revelation and allocation efficiency.
In this paper we circumvent Myerson and Satterthwaites impossibility result by introducing a new model of negotiationrange markets.
A negotiation-range mechanism does not produce payment prices for the market participants.
Rather, is assigns each buyer-seller pair a price range, called Zone Of Possible Agreements (ZOPA).
The buyer is provided with the high end of the range and the seller with the low end of the range.
This allows the trading parties to engage in negotiation over the final price with guarantee that the deal is beneficial for both of them.
The negotiation process is not considered part of the mechanism but left up to the interested parties, or to some external mechanism to perform.
In effect a negotiation-range mechanism operates as a mediator between the market participants, offering them the grounds to be able to finalize the terms of the trade by themselves.

This concept is natural to many real-world market environments such as the real estate market. 1 We focus on the single-unit heterogeneous setting: n sellers offer one unique good each by placing sealed bids specifying their willingness to sell, and m buyers, interested in buying a single good each, placing sealed bids specifying their willingness to pay for each good they may be interested in.
Our main result is a single-unit heterogeneous bilateral trade negotiation-range mechanism (ZOPAS) that is efficient, individually rational, incentive compatible and budget balanced.
Our result does not contradict Myerson and Satterthwaites important theorem.

Myerson-Satterthwaites proof relies on a theorem assuring that in two different efficient IC markets; if the sellers have the same upper bound utility then they will receive the same prices in each market and if the buyers have the same lower bound utility then they will receive the same prices in each market.
Our single-unit heterogeneous mechanism bypasses Myerson and Satterthwaites theorem by producing a price range, defined by a sellers floor and a buyers ceiling, for each pair of matched players.
In our market mechanism the sellers upper bound utility may be the same while the sellers floor is different and the buyers lower bound utility may be the same while the buyers ceiling is different.
Moreover, the final price is not fixed by the mechanism at all.
Instead, it is determined by an independent negotiation between the buyer and seller.
More specifically, in a negotiation-range mechanism, the range of prices each matched pair is given is resolved by a negotiation stage where a final price is determined.
This negotiation stage is crucial for our mechanism to be IC.
Intuitively, a negotiation range mechanism is incentive compatible if truth telling promises the best ZOPA from the point of view of the player in question.
That is, he would tell the truth if this strategy maximizes the upper and lower bounds on his utility as expressed by the ZOPA boundaries.
Yet, when carefully examined it turns out that it is impossible (by [10]) that this goal will always hold.
This is simply because such a mechanism could be easily modified to determine final prices for the players (e.g. by taking the average of the ranges boundaries).
Here, the negotiation stage come into play.

We show that if the above utility maximizing condition does not hold then it is the case that the player cannot influence the negotiation bound that is assigned to his deal partner no matter what value he declares.

This means that the only thing that he may achieve by reporting a false valuation is modifying his own negotiation bound, something that he could alternatively achieve by reporting his true valuation and incorporating the effect of the modified negotiation bound into his negotiation strategy.
This eliminates the benefit of reporting false valuations and allows our mechanism to compute the optimal gain from trade according to the players true values.

The problem of computing the optimal allocation which maximizes gain from trade can be conceptualized as the problem of finding the maximum weighted matching in a weighted bipartite graph connecting buyers and sellers, where each edge in the graph is assigned a weight equal to the difference between the respective buyer bid and seller bid.
It is well known that this problem can be solved efficiently in polynomial time.
VCG IC payment schemes [2, 7, 13] support efficient and IR bilateral trade but not simultaneously BB.
Our particular approach adapts the VCG payment scheme to achieve budget balance.
The philosophy of the VCG payment schemes in bilateral trade is that the buyer pays the sellers opportunity cost of not selling the good to another buyer and not keeping the good to herself.
The seller is paid in addition to the buyers price a compensation for the damage the mechanism did to the seller by not extracting the buyers full bid.
Our philosophy is a bit different: The seller is paid at least her opportunity cost of not selling the good to another buyer and not keeping the good for herself.
The buyer pays at most his alternate sellers opportunity cost of not selling the good to another buyer and not keeping the alternate good for herself.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows.
In Section 2 we describe our model and definitions.
In section 3 we present the single-unit heterogeneous negotiation-range mechanism and show that it is efficient, IR, IC and BB.
Finally, we conclude with a discussion in Section 4. 2.
NEGOTIATION MARKETS PRELIMINARIES Let Π denote the set of players, N the set of n selling players, and M the set of m buying players, where Π = N ∪ M. Let Ψ = {1, ..., t} denote the set of goods.
Let Ti ∈ {−1, 0, 1}t denote an exchange vector for a trade, such that player i buys goods {A ∈ Ψ|Ti (A) = 1} and sells goods {A ∈ Ψ|Ti (A) = −1}.
Let T = (T1, ..., T|Π|) denote the complete trade between all players.
We view T as describing the allocation of goods by the mechanism to the buyers and sellers.
In the single-unit heterogeneous setting every good belongs to specific seller, and every buyer is interested in buying one good.
The buyer may bid for several or all goods.
At the end of the auction every good is either assigned to one of the buyers who bid for it or kept unsold by the seller.
It is convenient to assume the sets of buyers and sellers are disjoint (though it is not required), i.e.
Each seller i is associated with exactly one good Ai, for which she has true valuation ci which expresses the price at which it is beneficial for her to sell the good.
If the seller reports a false valuation at an attempt to improve the auction results for her, this valuation is denoted ˆci.
A buyer has a valuation vector describing his valuation for each of the goods according to their owner.
Specifically, vj(k) denotes buyer js valuation for good Ak.
Similarly, if he reports a false valuation it is denoted ˆvj(k).
If buyer j is matched by the mechanism with seller i then Ti(Ai) = −1 and Tj(Ai) = 1.
Notice, that in our setting for every k = i, Ti(Ak) = 0 and Tj(Ai) = 0 and also for every z = j, Tz(Ai) = 0.
For a matched buyer j - seller i pair, the gain from trade on the deal is defined as vj(i) − ci.
Given and allocation T, the gain from trade associated with T is V = j∈M,i∈N (vj(i) − ci) · Tj(Ai).
Let T∗ denote the optimal allocation which maximizes the gain from trade, computed according to the players true valuations.
Let V ∗ denote the optimal gain from trade associated with this allocation.

When players report false valuations we use ˆT∗ and ˆV ∗ to denote the optimal allocation and gain from trade, respectively, when computed according to the reported valuations. 2 We are interested in the design of negotiation-range mechanisms.

In contrast to a standard auction mechanism where the buyer and seller are provided with the prices they should pay, the goal of a negotiation-range mechanism is to provide the players with a range of prices within which they can negotiate the final terms of the deal by themselves.
The mechanism would provide the buyer with the upper bound on the range and the seller with the lower bound on the range.
This gives each of them a promise that it will be beneficial for them to close the deal, but does not provide information about the other players terms of negotiation.
Definition 1.
Negotiation Range: Zone Of Possible Agreements, ZOPA, between a matched buyer and seller.
The ZOPA is a range, (L, H), 0 ≤ L ≤ H, where H is an upper bound (ceiling) price for the buyer and L is a lower bound (floor) price for the seller.
Definition 2.

Negotiation-Range Mechanism: A mechanism that computes a ZOPA, (L, H), for each matched buyer and seller in T∗ , and provides the buyer with the upper bound H and the seller with the lower bound L. The basic assumption is that participants in the auction are self-interested players.
That is their main goal is to maximize their expected utility.
The utility for a buyer who does not participate in the trade is 0.
If he does win some good, his utility is the surplus between his valuation for that good and the price he pays.
For a seller, if she keeps the good unsold, her utility is just her valuation of the good, and the surplus is 0.
If she gets to sell it, her utility is the price she is paid for it, and the surplus is the difference between this price and her valuation.

Since negotiation-range mechanisms assign bounds on the range of prices rather than the final price, it is useful to define the upper and lower bounds on the players utilities defined by the ranges limits.
Definition 3.

Consider a buyer j - seller i pair matched by a negotiation-range mechanism and let (L, H) be their associated negotiation range. • The buyers top utility is: vj(i) − L, and the buyers bottom utility is vj(i) − H. • The sellers top utility is H, with surplus H − ci, and the sellers bottom utility is L, with surplus L − ci. 3.

THE SINGLE-UNIT HETEROGENEOUS MECHANISM (ZOPAS) 3.1 Description of the Mechanism ZOPAS is a negotiation-range mechanism, it finds the optimal allocation T∗ and uses it to define a ZOPA for each buyer-seller pair.
The first stage in applying the mechanism is for the buyers and sellers to submit their sealed bids.
The mechanism then allocates buyers to sellers by computing the allocation T ∗ , which results in the optimal gain from trade V ∗ , and defines a ZOPA for each buyer-seller pair.
Finally, buyers and sellers use the ZOPA to negotiate a final price.

The maximum weighted matching problem in solvable in polynomial time (e.g., using the Hungarian Method).
This results in a matching between buyers and sellers that maximizes gain from trade.
The next step is to compute for each buyer-seller pair a sellers floor, which provides the lower bound of the ZOPA for this pair, and assigns it to the seller.

A sellers floor is computed by calculating the difference between the total gain from trade when the buyer is excluded and the total gain from trade of the other participants when the buyer is included (the VCG principle).
Let (T−j)∗ denote the gain from trade of the optimal allocation when buyer js bids are discarded.
Denote by (V−j)∗ the total gain from trade in the allocation (T−j)∗ .
Definition 4.
Seller Floor: The lowest price the seller should expect to receive, communicated to the seller by the mechanism.
The seller floor for player i who was matched with buyer j on good Ai, i.e., Tj(Ai) = 1, is computed as: Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ .
The seller is instructed not to accept less than this price from her matched buyer.
Next, the mechanism computes for each buyer-seller pair a buyer ceiling, which provides the upper bound of the ZOPA for this pair, and assigns it to the buyer.

Each buyers ceiling is computed by removing the buyers matched seller and calculating the difference between the total gain from trade when the buyer is excluded and the total gain from trade of the other participants when the 3 buyer is included.
Let (T−i )∗ denote the gain from trade of the optimal allocation when seller i is removed from the trade.
Denote by (V −i )∗ the total gain from trade in the allocation (T−i )∗ .
Let (T−i −j )∗ denote the gain from trade of the optimal allocation when seller i is removed from the trade and buyer js bids are discarded.
Denote by (V −i −j )∗ the total gain from trade in the allocation (T −i −j )∗ .
Definition 5.
Buyer Ceiling: The highest price the seller should expect to pay, communicated to the buyer by the mechanism.
The buyer ceiling for player j who was matched with seller i on good Ai, i.e., Tj(Ai) = 1, is computed as: Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗ .
The buyer is instructed not to pay more than this price to his matched seller.
Once the negotiation range lower bound and upper bound are computed for every matched pair, the mechanism reports the lower bound price to the seller and the upper bound price to the buyer.
At this point each buyer-seller pair negotiates on the final price and concludes the deal.
A schematic description the ZOPAS mechanism is given in Figure 3.1. 3.2 Analysis of the Mechanism In this section we analyze the properties of the ZOPAS mechanism.
Theorem 1.
The ZOPAS market negotiation-range mechanism is an incentive-compatible bilateral trade mechanism that is efficient, individually rational and budget balanced.
Clearly ZOPAS is an efficient polynomial time mechanism.
Let us show it satisfies the rest of the properties in the theorem.
Claim 1.
ZOPAS is individually rational, i.e., the mechanism maintains nonnegative utility surplus for all participants.
Proof.
If a participant does not trade in the optimal allocation then his utility surplus is zero by definition.
Consider a pair of buyer j and seller i which are matched in the optimal allocation T ∗ .
Then the buyers utility is at least vj(i) − Hj.
Recall that Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗ , so that vj(i) − Hj = (V −i )∗ − (V −i −j )∗ .
Since the optimal gain from trade which includes j is higher than that which does not, we have that the utility is nonnegative: vj(i) − Hj ≥ 0.
Now, consider the seller i.
Her utility surplus is at least Li − ci.
Recall that Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ .
If we removed from the optimal allocation T ∗ the contribution of the buyer j - seller i pair, we are left with an allocation which excludes j, and has value V ∗ − (vj(i) − ci).
This implies that (V−j)∗ ≥ V ∗ − vj(i) + ci, which implies that Li − ci ≥ 0.

The fact that ZOPAS is a budget-balanced mechanism follows from the following lemma which ensures the validity of the negotiation range, i.e., that every sellers floor is below her matched buyers ceiling.
This ensures that they can close the deal at a final price which lies in this range.
Lemma 1.
For every buyer j- seller i pair matched by the mechanism: Li ≤ Hj.
Proof.
Recall that Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ and Hj = vj(i)+(V −i −j )∗ −(V −i )∗ .
To prove that Li ≤ Hj it is enough to show that (V −i )∗ + (V−j)∗ ≤ V ∗ + (V −i −j )∗ . (1) The proof of (1) is based on a method which we apply several times in our analysis.
We start with the allocations (T−i )∗ and (T−j)∗ which together have value equal to (V −i )∗ + (V−j)∗ .
We now use them to create a pair of new valid allocations, by using the same pairs that were matched in the original allocations.
This means that the sum of values of the new allocations is the same as the original pair of allocations.
We also require that one of the new allocations does not include buyer j or seller i.
This means that the sum of values of these new allocations is at most V ∗ + (V −i −j )∗ , which proves (1).

Let G be the bipartite graph where the nodes on one side of G represent the buyers and the nodes on the other side represent the sellers, and edge weights represent the gain from trade for the particular pair.

The different allocations represent bipartite matchings in G. It will be convenient for the sake of our argument to think of the edges that belong to each of the matchings as being colored with a specific color representing this matching.
Assign color 1 to the edges in the matching (T −i )∗ and assign color 2 to the edges in the matching (T−j)∗ .
We claim that these edges can be recolored using colors 3 and 4 so that the new coloring represents allocations T (represented by color 3) and (T−i −j ) (represented by color 4).
This implies the that inequality (1) holds.

Define an alternating path P starting at j.
Let S1 be the seller matched to j in (T −i )∗ (if none exists then P is empty).
Let B1 be the buyer matched to S1 in (T−j)∗ , S2 be the seller matched to B1 in (T−i )∗ , B2 be the buyer matched to S2 in (T−j)∗ , and so on.
This defines an alternating path P, starting at j, whose edges colors alternate between colors 1 and 2 (starting with 1).
This path ends either in a seller who is not matched in (T−j)∗ or in a buyer who is not matched in (T−i )∗ .
Since all sellers in this path are matched in (T−i )∗ , we have that seller i does not belong to P. This ensures that edges in P may be colored by alternating colors 3 and 4 (starting with 3).
Since except for the first edge, all others do not involve i or j and thus may be colored 4 and be part of an allocation (T −i −j ) .

We are left to recolor the edges that do not belong to P. Since none of these edges includes j we have that the edges that were colored 1, which are part of (T −i )∗ , may now be colored 4, and be included in the allocation (T −i −j ) .
It is also clear that the edges that were colored 2, which are part of (T−j)∗ , may now be colored 3, and be included in the allocation T .
This completes the proof of the lemma. 3.3 Incentive Compatibility The basic requirement in mechanism design is for an exchange mechanism to be incentive compatible.

This means that its payment structure enforces that truth-telling is the players weakly dominant strategy, that is that the strategy by which the player is stating his true valuation results 4 ... jS1 S2 B1 S3 B2 B3S4 S5 B4 S6 B5 S8 B7 S7 B6 ...

The utility surplus is defined as the absolute difference between the players bid and his price.
Negotiation-range mechanisms assign bounds on the range of prices rather than the final price and therefore the players valuation only influences the minimum and maximum bounds on his utility.
For a buyer the minimum (bottom) utility would be based on the top of the negotiation range (ceiling), and the maximum (top) utility would be based on the bottom of the negotiation range (floor).
For a seller its the other way around.

Therefore the basic natural requirement from negotiation-range mechanisms would be that stating the players true valuation results in both the higher bottom utility and higher top utility for the player, compared with other strategies.
Unfortunately, this requirement is still too strong and it is impossible (by [10]) that this will always hold.
Therefore we slightly relax it as follows: we require this holds when the false valuation based strategy changes the players allocation.
When the allocation stays unchanged we require instead that the player would not be able to change his matched players bound (e.g. a buyer cannot change the sellers floor).
This means that the only thing he can influence is his own bound, something that he can alternatively achieve through means of negotiation.
The following formally summarizes our incentive compatibility requirements from the negotiation-range mechanism.

CONCLUSIONS AND EXTENSIONS In this paper we suggest a way to deal with the impossibility of producing mechanisms which are efficient, individually rational, incentive compatible and budget balanced.
To this aim we introduce the concept of negotiation-range mechanisms which avoid the problem by leaving the final determination of prices to a negotiation between the buyer and seller.
The goal of the mechanism is to provide the initial range (ZOPA) for negotiation in a way that it will be beneficial for the participants to close the proposed deals.
We present a negotiation range mechanism that is efficient, individually rational, incentive compatible and budget balanced.
The ZOPA produced by our mechanism is based 7 on a natural adaptation of the VCG payment scheme in a way that promises valid negotiation ranges which permit a budget balanced allocation.
The basic question that we aimed to tackle seems very exciting: which properties can we expect a market mechanism to achieve ?
Are there different market models and requirements from the mechanisms that are more feasible than classic mechanism design goals ?
In the context of our negotiation-range model, is natural to further study negotiation based mechanisms in more general settings.
A natural extension is that of a combinatorial market.

Unfortunately, finding the optimal allocation in a combinatorial setting is NP-hard, and thus the problem of maintaining BB is compounded by the problem of maintaining IC when efficiency is approximated [1, 5, 6, 9, 11].
Applying the approach in this paper to develop negotiationrange mechanisms for combinatorial markets, even in restricted settings, seems a promising direction for research. 5.

This model allows us to circumvent Myerson and Satterthwaites impossibility result and present a bilateral market mechanism that is efficient, individually rational, incentive compatible and budget balanced in the single-unit heterogeneous setting.

The underlying scheme makes this combination of desirable qualities possible by reporting a price range for each buyer-seller pair that defines a zone of possible agreements, while the final price is left open for negotiation.

INTRODUCTION In this paper we introduce the concept of negotiation based mechanisms in the context of the theory of efficient truthful markets.
A market consists of multiple buyers and sellers who wish to exchange goods.
The markets main objective is to produce an allocation of sellers goods to buyers as to maximize the total gain from trade.
A commonly studied model of participant behavior is taken from the field of economic mechanism design [3, 4, 11].
In this model each player has a private valuation function that assigns real values to each possible allocation.
The algorithm motivates players to participate truthfully by handing payments to them.
The mechanism in an exchange collects buyer bids and seller bids and clears the exchange by computing:(i) a set of trades, and (ii) the payments made and received by players.
In designing a mechanism to compute trades and payments we must consider the bidding strategies of self-interested players, i.e. rational players that follow expected-utility maximizing strategies.
We set allocative efficiency as our primary goal.
That is the mechanism must compute a set of trades that maximizes gain from trade.

In addition we require
individual rationality
(IR) so that all players have positive expected utility to participate, budget balance (BB) so that the exchange does not run at a loss, and incentive compatibility (IC) so that reporting the truth is a dominant strategy for each player.

Unfortunately, Myerson and Satterthwaites (1983) well known result demonstrates that in bilateral trade it is impossible to simultaneously achieve perfect efficiency, BB, and IR using an IC mechanism [10].
A unique approach to overcome Myerson and Satterthwaites impossibility result was attempted by Parkes, Kalagnanam and Eso [12].
This result designs both a regular and a combinatorial bilateral trade mechanism (which imposes BB and IR) that approximates truth revelation and allocation efficiency.
In this paper we circumvent Myerson and Satterthwaites impossibility result by introducing a new model of negotiationrange markets.
A negotiation-range mechanism does not produce payment prices for the market participants.
Rather, is assigns each buyer-seller pair a price range, called Zone Of Possible Agreements (ZOPA).
The buyer is provided with the high end of the range and the seller with the low end of the range.
This allows the trading parties to engage in negotiation over the final price with guarantee that the deal is beneficial for both of them.
The negotiation process is not considered part of the mechanism but left up to the interested parties, or to some external mechanism to perform.
In effect a negotiation-range mechanism operates as a mediator between the market participants, offering them the grounds to be able to finalize the terms of the trade by themselves.

This concept is natural to many real-world market environments such as the real estate market. 1 We focus on the single-unit heterogeneous setting: n sellers offer one unique good each by placing sealed bids specifying their willingness to sell, and m buyers, interested in buying a single good each, placing sealed bids specifying their willingness to pay for each good they may be interested in.
Our main result is a single-unit heterogeneous bilateral trade negotiation-range mechanism (ZOPAS) that is efficient, individually rational, incentive compatible and budget balanced.
Our result does not contradict Myerson and Satterthwaites important theorem.

Myerson-Satterthwaites proof relies on a theorem assuring that in two different efficient IC markets; if the sellers have the same upper bound utility then they will receive the same prices in each market and if the buyers have the same lower bound utility then they will receive the same prices in each market.
Our single-unit heterogeneous mechanism bypasses Myerson and Satterthwaites theorem by producing a price range, defined by a sellers floor and a buyers ceiling, for each pair of matched players.
In our market mechanism the sellers upper bound utility may be the same while the sellers floor is different and the buyers lower bound utility may be the same while the buyers ceiling is different.
Moreover, the final price is not fixed by the mechanism at all.
Instead, it is determined by an independent negotiation between the buyer and seller.
More specifically, in a negotiation-range mechanism, the range of prices each matched pair is given is resolved by a negotiation stage where a final price is determined.
This negotiation stage is crucial for our mechanism to be IC.
Intuitively, a negotiation range mechanism is incentive compatible if truth telling promises the best ZOPA from the point of view of the player in question.
That is, he would tell the truth if this strategy maximizes the upper and lower bounds on his utility as expressed by the ZOPA boundaries.
Yet, when carefully examined it turns out that it is impossible (by [10]) that this goal will always hold.
This is simply because such a mechanism could be easily modified to determine final prices for the players (e.g. by taking the average of the ranges boundaries).
Here, the negotiation stage come into play.

We show that if the above utility maximizing condition does not hold then it is the case that the player cannot influence the negotiation bound that is assigned to his deal partner no matter what value he declares.

This means that the only thing that he may achieve by reporting a false valuation is modifying his own negotiation bound, something that he could alternatively achieve by reporting his true valuation and incorporating the effect of the modified negotiation bound into his negotiation strategy.
This eliminates the benefit of reporting false valuations and allows our mechanism to compute the optimal gain from trade according to the players true values.

The problem of computing the optimal allocation which maximizes gain from trade can be conceptualized as the problem of finding the maximum weighted matching in a weighted bipartite graph connecting buyers and sellers, where each edge in the graph is assigned a weight equal to the difference between the respective buyer bid and seller bid.
It is well known that this problem can be solved efficiently in polynomial time.
VCG IC payment schemes [2, 7, 13] support efficient and IR bilateral trade but not simultaneously BB.
Our particular approach adapts the VCG payment scheme to achieve budget balance.
The philosophy of the VCG payment schemes in bilateral trade is that the buyer pays the sellers opportunity cost of not selling the good to another buyer and not keeping the good to herself.
The seller is paid in addition to the buyers price a compensation for the damage the mechanism did to the seller by not extracting the buyers full bid.
Our philosophy is a bit different: The seller is paid at least her opportunity cost of not selling the good to another buyer and not keeping the good for herself.
The buyer pays at most his alternate sellers opportunity cost of not selling the good to another buyer and not keeping the alternate good for herself.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows.
In Section 2 we describe our model and definitions.
In section 3 we present the single-unit heterogeneous negotiation-range mechanism and show that it is efficient, IR, IC and BB.
Finally, we conclude with a discussion in Section 4. 2.
NEGOTIATION MARKETS PRELIMINARIES Let Π denote the set of players, N the set of n selling players, and M the set of m buying players, where Π = N ∪ M. Let Ψ = {1, ..., t} denote the set of goods.
Let Ti ∈ {−1, 0, 1}t denote an exchange vector for a trade, such that player i buys goods {A ∈ Ψ|Ti (A) = 1} and sells goods {A ∈ Ψ|Ti (A) = −1}.
Let T = (T1, ..., T|Π|) denote the complete trade between all players.
We view T as describing the allocation of goods by the mechanism to the buyers and sellers.
In the single-unit heterogeneous setting every good belongs to specific seller, and every buyer is interested in buying one good.
The buyer may bid for several or all goods.
At the end of the auction every good is either assigned to one of the buyers who bid for it or kept unsold by the seller.
It is convenient to assume the sets of buyers and sellers are disjoint (though it is not required), i.e.
Each seller i is associated with exactly one good Ai, for which she has true valuation ci which expresses the price at which it is beneficial for her to sell the good.
If the seller reports a false valuation at an attempt to improve the auction results for her, this valuation is denoted ˆci.
A buyer has a valuation vector describing his valuation for each of the goods according to their owner.
Specifically, vj(k) denotes buyer js valuation for good Ak.
Similarly, if he reports a false valuation it is denoted ˆvj(k).
If buyer j is matched by the mechanism with seller i then Ti(Ai) = −1 and Tj(Ai) = 1.
Notice, that in our setting for every k = i, Ti(Ak) = 0 and Tj(Ai) = 0 and also for every z = j, Tz(Ai) = 0.
For a matched buyer j - seller i pair, the gain from trade on the deal is defined as vj(i) − ci.
Given and allocation T, the gain from trade associated with T is V = j∈M,i∈N (vj(i) − ci) · Tj(Ai).
Let T∗ denote the optimal allocation which maximizes the gain from trade, computed according to the players true valuations.
Let V ∗ denote the optimal gain from trade associated with this allocation.

When players report false valuations we use ˆT∗ and ˆV ∗ to denote the optimal allocation and gain from trade, respectively, when computed according to the reported valuations. 2 We are interested in the design of negotiation-range mechanisms.

In contrast to a standard auction mechanism where the buyer and seller are provided with the prices they should pay, the goal of a negotiation-range mechanism is to provide the players with a range of prices within which they can negotiate the final terms of the deal by themselves.
The mechanism would provide the buyer with the upper bound on the range and the seller with the lower bound on the range.
This gives each of them a promise that it will be beneficial for them to close the deal, but does not provide information about the other players terms of negotiation.
Definition 1.
Negotiation Range: Zone Of Possible Agreements, ZOPA, between a matched buyer and seller.
The ZOPA is a range, (L, H), 0 ≤ L ≤ H, where H is an upper bound (ceiling) price for the buyer and L is a lower bound (floor) price for the seller.
Definition 2.

Negotiation-Range Mechanism: A mechanism that computes a ZOPA, (L, H), for each matched buyer and seller in T∗ , and provides the buyer with the upper bound H and the seller with the lower bound L. The basic assumption is that participants in the auction are self-interested players.
That is their main goal is to maximize their expected utility.
The utility for a buyer who does not participate in the trade is 0.
If he does win some good, his utility is the surplus between his valuation for that good and the price he pays.
For a seller, if she keeps the good unsold, her utility is just her valuation of the good, and the surplus is 0.
If she gets to sell it, her utility is the price she is paid for it, and the surplus is the difference between this price and her valuation.

Since negotiation-range mechanisms assign bounds on the range of prices rather than the final price, it is useful to define the upper and lower bounds on the players utilities defined by the ranges limits.
Definition 3.

Consider a buyer j - seller i pair matched by a negotiation-range mechanism and let (L, H) be their associated negotiation range. • The buyers top utility is: vj(i) − L, and the buyers bottom utility is vj(i) − H. • The sellers top utility is H, with surplus H − ci, and the sellers bottom utility is L, with surplus L − ci. 3.

THE SINGLE-UNIT HETEROGENEOUS MECHANISM (ZOPAS) 3.1 Description of the Mechanism ZOPAS is a negotiation-range mechanism, it finds the optimal allocation T∗ and uses it to define a ZOPA for each buyer-seller pair.
The first stage in applying the mechanism is for the buyers and sellers to submit their sealed bids.
The mechanism then allocates buyers to sellers by computing the allocation T ∗ , which results in the optimal gain from trade V ∗ , and defines a ZOPA for each buyer-seller pair.
Finally, buyers and sellers use the ZOPA to negotiate a final price.

The next step is to compute for each buyer-seller pair a sellers floor, which provides the lower bound of the ZOPA for this pair, and assigns it to the seller.

A sellers floor is computed by calculating the difference between the total gain from trade when the buyer is excluded and the total gain from trade of the other participants when the buyer is included (the VCG principle).
Let (T−j)∗ denote the gain from trade of the optimal allocation when buyer js bids are discarded.
Denote by (V−j)∗ the total gain from trade in the allocation (T−j)∗ .
Definition 4.
Seller Floor: The lowest price the seller should expect to receive, communicated to the seller by the mechanism.
The seller floor for player i who was matched with buyer j on good Ai, i.e., Tj(Ai) = 1, is computed as: Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ .
The seller is instructed not to accept less than this price from her matched buyer.
Next, the mechanism computes for each buyer-seller pair a buyer ceiling, which provides the upper bound of the ZOPA for this pair, and assigns it to the buyer.

Each buyers ceiling is computed by removing the buyers matched seller and calculating the difference between the total gain from trade when the buyer is excluded and the total gain from trade of the other participants when the 3 buyer is included.
Let (T−i )∗ denote the gain from trade of the optimal allocation when seller i is removed from the trade.
Denote by (V −i )∗ the total gain from trade in the allocation (T−i )∗ .

Denote by (V −i −j )∗ the total gain from trade in the allocation (T −i −j )∗ .
Definition 5.
Buyer Ceiling: The highest price the seller should expect to pay, communicated to the buyer by the mechanism.
The buyer ceiling for player j who was matched with seller i on good Ai, i.e., Tj(Ai) = 1, is computed as: Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗ .
The buyer is instructed not to pay more than this price to his matched seller.
Once the negotiation range lower bound and upper bound are computed for every matched pair, the mechanism reports the lower bound price to the seller and the upper bound price to the buyer.
At this point each buyer-seller pair negotiates on the final price and concludes the deal.
A schematic description the ZOPAS mechanism is given in Figure 3.1. 3.2 Analysis of the Mechanism In this section we analyze the properties of the ZOPAS mechanism.
Theorem 1.
The ZOPAS market negotiation-range mechanism is an incentive-compatible bilateral trade mechanism that is efficient, individually rational and budget balanced.
Clearly ZOPAS is an efficient polynomial time mechanism.
Let us show it satisfies the rest of the properties in the theorem.
Claim 1.
ZOPAS is individually rational, i.e., the mechanism maintains nonnegative utility surplus for all participants.
Proof.
If a participant does not trade in the optimal allocation then his utility surplus is zero by definition.
Consider a pair of buyer j and seller i which are matched in the optimal allocation T ∗ .
Then the buyers utility is at least vj(i) − Hj.
Recall that Hj = vj(i) + (V −i −j )∗ − (V −i )∗ , so that vj(i) − Hj = (V −i )∗ − (V −i −j )∗ .
Since the optimal gain from trade which includes j is higher than that which does not, we have that the utility is nonnegative: vj(i) − Hj ≥ 0.
Now, consider the seller i.
Her utility surplus is at least Li − ci.
Recall that Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ .
If we removed from the optimal allocation T ∗ the contribution of the buyer j - seller i pair, we are left with an allocation which excludes j, and has value V ∗ − (vj(i) − ci).
This implies that (V−j)∗ ≥ V ∗ − vj(i) + ci, which implies that Li − ci ≥ 0.

The fact that ZOPAS is a budget-balanced mechanism follows from the following lemma which ensures the validity of the negotiation range, i.e., that every sellers floor is below her matched buyers ceiling.
This ensures that they can close the deal at a final price which lies in this range.
Lemma 1.
For every buyer j- seller i pair matched by the mechanism: Li ≤ Hj.
Proof.
Recall that Li = vj(i) + (V−j)∗ − V ∗ and Hj = vj(i)+(V −i −j )∗ −(V −i )∗ .
To prove that Li ≤ Hj it is enough to show that (V −i )∗ + (V−j)∗ ≤ V ∗ + (V −i −j )∗ . (1) The proof of (1) is based on a method which we apply several times in our analysis.
We start with the allocations (T−i )∗ and (T−j)∗ which together have value equal to (V −i )∗ + (V−j)∗ .
We now use them to create a pair of new valid allocations, by using the same pairs that were matched in the original allocations.
This means that the sum of values of the new allocations is the same as the original pair of allocations.
We also require that one of the new allocations does not include buyer j or seller i.
This means that the sum of values of these new allocations is at most V ∗ + (V −i −j )∗ , which proves (1).

Let G be the bipartite graph where the nodes on one side of G represent the buyers and the nodes on the other side represent the sellers, and edge weights represent the gain from trade for the particular pair.

The different allocations represent bipartite matchings in G. It will be convenient for the sake of our argument to think of the edges that belong to each of the matchings as being colored with a specific color representing this matching.
Assign color 1 to the edges in the matching (T −i )∗ and assign color 2 to the edges in the matching (T−j)∗ .
We claim that these edges can be recolored using colors 3 and 4 so that the new coloring represents allocations T (represented by color 3) and (T−i −j ) (represented by color 4).
This implies the that inequality (1) holds.
Figure 2 illustrates the graph G and the colorings of the different matchings.
Define an alternating path P starting at j.
Let S1 be the seller matched to j in (T −i )∗ (if none exists then P is empty).
Let B1 be the buyer matched to S1 in (T−j)∗ , S2 be the seller matched to B1 in (T−i )∗ , B2 be the buyer matched to S2 in (T−j)∗ , and so on.
This defines an alternating path P, starting at j, whose edges colors alternate between colors 1 and 2 (starting with 1).
This path ends either in a seller who is not matched in (T−j)∗ or in a buyer who is not matched in (T−i )∗ .
Since all sellers in this path are matched in (T−i )∗ , we have that seller i does not belong to P. This ensures that edges in P may be colored by alternating colors 3 and 4 (starting with 3).
Since except for the first edge, all others do not involve i or j and thus may be colored 4 and be part of an allocation (T −i −j ) .

We are left to recolor the edges that do not belong to P. Since none of these edges includes j we have that the edges that were colored 1, which are part of (T −i )∗ , may now be colored 4, and be included in the allocation (T −i −j ) .
It is also clear that the edges that were colored 2, which are part of (T−j)∗ , may now be colored 3, and be included in the allocation T .
This completes the proof of the lemma. 3.3 Incentive Compatibility The basic requirement in mechanism design is for an exchange mechanism to be incentive compatible.

This means that its payment structure enforces that truth-telling is the players weakly dominant strategy, that is that the strategy by which the player is stating his true valuation results 4 ... jS1 S2 B1 S3 B2 B3S4 S5 B4 S6 B5 S8 B7 S7 B6 ...
